item.title: Associahedron
item.author: tkmharris@protonmail.com (Tom Harris)
item.description:
Jean-Louis Loday’s realisation of the (5-)associahedron:

The vertices are generated from planar binary trees using the algorithm described in Loday’s paper1 (Loday gives vertices in 4-space but they sit in a 3-dimsional hyperplane which I’ve projected onto ordinary 3-space). The surface was created and written to STL with the Trimesh Python library. Code.

  1. Loday, J-L. Realization of the Stasheff polytope. Archiv der Mathematik 83, 267–278 (2004). doi ↩︎

item.title: Herb
item.author: tkmharris@protonmail.com (Tom Harris)
item.description:
From an amazon.com review of Lewis & Papadimitrious’s Elements of the Theory of Computation:

And also… who the hell is this geek on the cover? It doesn’t reveal his identity anywhere in the book. You know this book is bad when they have a herb like him staring at you. This guy needs a new suit, a haircut, and he needs to learn how to smile.

The herb

item.title: Latin Wiphala
item.author: tkmharris@protonmail.com (Tom Harris)
item.description: I’ve been playing with Latin squares today. Here is a wiphala arranged in the pattern of the 7 by 7 Latin square used on the cover of Ronald Fisher’s The Design of Experiments.

item.title: Haskell Akiyama–Tanigawa
item.author: tkmharris@protonmail.com (Tom Harris)
item.description:
I am a big fan of the Akiyama–Tanigawa algorithm12 for computing Bernoulli numbers. It works by generating a structure resembling Pascal’s triangle, with rows whose entries are determined by a simple calculation on the two entries above them, from which we can read off the sequence of Bernoulli numbers.

What I like about this algorithm, besides its simplicity and elegance, is that it admits a concordantly simple and elgant implementation in Haskell using infinite data structures.

item.title: Books 2015 –
item.author: tkmharris@protonmail.com (Tom Harris)
item.description:
All the books I read since 2015. I also have a wishlist.

Rubric

Re-reads are marked with an asterisk (∗).
Works read in translation are marked with a dagger (†).
Things I read for book club are marked with a tilde (~).

2024

  1. Where the Crawdads Sing, Delia Owens. ~

  2. The Picses, Melissa Broder.

  3. Several People Are Typing, Calvin Kasulke.

item.title: Maths
item.author: tkmharris@protonmail.com (Tom Harris)
item.description:
I used to do research in pure maths. Here is the proof.

Publications

  1. Binary Complexes and Algebraic K-theory.
    (PhD thesis)
    Southampton ePrints

  2. Algebraic proofs of some fundamental theorems in algebraic K-theory.
    arXiv, published

  3. Exterior power operations on higher K-groups via binary complexes.
    (with Bernhard Köck and Lenny Taelman)
    arXiv, published

  4. Two Formulae for exterior power operations on higher K-groups.
    (with Bernhard Köck)
    arXiv, published
